title: ci: auto-rerun codecov

labels.name: review/triage-pending
labels.description: PRs opened by external contributors that are waiting for the 1st review

body:
### What does this PR do?
This PR implements github rererun workflows for codecov.

### Why is this change needed?
Using the GitHub CLI, this workaround reruns the original workflow if it fails, up to a retry limit, and introduces a secondary workflow that can be triggered via `workflow_dispatch`. By automatically retrying failed workflow runs, this method improves CI reliability without requiring manual intervention and makes it possible to programmatically handle faulty tests or temporary failures.

### Testing
WIll be tested in the github actions

### Documentation
Reference recommendation: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/67654#discussioncomment-8038649

### Related issues
Closes #2825

---
> Please let me know if you have feedback or require any changes.

title: gnovm: `gno test` error on external test pkg
body:
## Description

I have 3 files all in the same directory with a gno.mod that contains: `module gno.land/p/samourai/bug`

bug.gno:
```go
package bug

func SimpleFunction() {
	return
}
```

bug_test.gno
```go
package bug

import (
	"testing"
)

func TestSimple(t *testing.T) {
	SimpleFunction()
}
```

bug_test2.gno
```go
package bug_test

import (
	"testing"

	"gno.land/p/samourai/bug"
)

func TestSimple(t *testing.T) {
	bug.SimpleFunction()
}

```

before commit #4264 it was working fine, now it raise error:

```
~/.../examples @e3139524 ?1 ‚ùØ git checkout c0b0f863a387995001d4188ea2d10b086529b33b                                                                                                  4s 16:45:25
Previous HEAD position was e31395247 feat(commondao): add render support (#4270)
HEAD is now at c0b0f863a feat: transpile to Gno 0.9 (latest interrealm spec) with @cross (#4264)

... (make install & make build in ./gnovm)

~/.../examples @c0b0f863 ?1 ‚ùØ go run ../gnovm/cmd/gno test -failfast -v ./gno.land/p/samourai/bug                                                                                       16:45:37
gno.land/p/samourai/bug/bug2_test.gno:4:2: "testing" imported and not used (code=gnoTypeCheckError)
gno.land/p/samourai/bug/bug2_test.gno:4:2: "testing" imported and not used (code=gnoTypeCheckError)
gno.land/p/samourai/bug/bug_test.gno:6:2: could not import gno.land/p/samourai/bug (gno.land/p/samourai/bug/bug2_test.gno:4:2: "testing" imported and not used) (code=gnoTypeCheckError)
FAIL    ./gno.land/p/samourai/bug 	1.22s
FAIL
FAIL: 0 build errors, 1 test errors
exit status 1
```

```
~/.../examples @c0b0f863 ?1 ‚ùØ git checkout e31395247f3aceb5e2e1dfbf550e5992b6ac14ff                                                                                                  5s 16:45:44
Previous HEAD position was c0b0f863a feat: transpile to Gno 0.9 (latest interrealm spec) with @cross (#4264)
HEAD is now at e31395247 feat(commondao): add render support (#4270)

... (make install & make build in ./gnovm)

~/.../examples @e3139524 ?1 ‚ùØ go run ../gnovm/cmd/gno test -failfast -v ./gno.land/p/samourai/bug                                                                                       16:45:49
=== RUN   TestSimple
--- PASS: TestSimple (0.00s)
=== RUN   TestSimple
--- PASS: TestSimple (0.00s)
ok      ./gno.land/p/samourai/bug 	1.43s
```

If this is the expected behavior, i suggest to adapt the resulting error to be explicit

title: slice cannot be converted to array
body:
## Description

this panic in gno but should work:
```go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	s := []byte("hello")   // len(s) == 5
	arr := ([5]byte)(s) // Convert to [5]byte
}
```

Updates `go.opentelemetry.io/otel` from 1.34.0 to 1.36.0
Changelog

Sourced from go.opentelemetry.io/otel's changelog.

[1.36.0/0.58.0/0.12.0] 2025-05-20

Added

  • Add exponential histogram support in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6421)
  • The go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.31.0 package. The package contains semantic conventions from the v1.31.0 version of the OpenTelemetry Semantic Conventions. See the migration documentation for information on how to upgrade from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.30.0. (#6479)
  • Add Recording, Scope, and Record types in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6507)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlptrace/otlptracehttp. (#6751)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlpmetric/otlpmetrichttp. (#6752)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploghttp. (#6688)
  • Add ValuesGetter in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation, a TextMapCarrier that supports retrieving multiple values for a single key. (#5973)
  • Add Values method to HeaderCarrier to implement the new ValuesGetter interface in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation. (#5973)
  • Update Baggage in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation to retrieve multiple values for a key when the carrier implements ValuesGetter. (#5973)
  • Add AssertEqual function in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6662)
  • The go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.32.0 package. The package contains semantic conventions from the v1.32.0 version of the OpenTelemetry Semantic Conventions. See the migration documentation for information on how to upgrade from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.31.0(#6782)
  • Add Transform option in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6794)
  • Add Desc option in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6796)

Removed

  • Drop support for [Go 1.22]. (#6381, #6418)
  • Remove Resource field from EnabledParameters in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log. (#6494)
  • Remove RecordFactory type from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6492)
  • Remove ScopeRecords, EmittedRecord, and RecordFactory types from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6507)
  • Remove AssertRecordEqual function in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest, use AssertEqual instead. (#6662)

Changed

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Update github.com/prometheus/client_golang to v1.21.1, which changes the NameValidationScheme to UTF8Validation. This allows metrics names to keep original delimiters (e.g. .), rather than replacing with underscores. This can be reverted by setting github.com/prometheus/common/model.NameValidationScheme to LegacyValidation in github.com/prometheus/common/model. (#6433)
  • Initialize map with len(keys) in NewAllowKeysFilter and NewDenyKeysFilter to avoid unnecessary allocations in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/attribute. (#6455)
  • go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest is now a separate Go module. (#6465)
  • go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log/logtest is now a separate Go module. (#6466)
  • Recorder in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest no longer separately stores records emitted by loggers with the same instrumentation scope. (#6507)
  • Improve performance of BatchProcessor in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log by not exporting when exporter cannot accept more. (#6569, #6641)

Deprecated

  • Deprecate support for model.LegacyValidation for go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6449)

Fixes

  • Stop percent encoding header environment variables in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploggrpc and go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploghttp. (#6392)
  • Ensure the noopSpan.tracerProvider method is not inlined in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/trace so the go.opentelemetry.io/auto instrumentation can instrument non-recording spans. (#6456)
  • Use a sync.Pool instead of allocating metricdata.ResourceMetrics in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6472)

... (truncated)

Commits
  • a85ae98 Release v1.36.0/v0.58.0/v0.12.0 (#6793)
  • 3f85c35 logtest: add Desc (#6796)
  • d2fff76 chore(deps): update module github.com/uudashr/iface to v1.4.0 (#6798)
  • 2d4c9dc Add semconv/v1.32.0 (#6782)
  • fe523bd logtest: add Transform (#6794)
  • e578799 fix(deps): update googleapis to 55703ea (#6795)
  • af189e5 chore(deps): update module github.com/golangci/misspell to v0.7.0 (#6792)
  • 836a2ce chore(deps): update module github.com/alecthomas/chroma/v2 to v2.18.0 (#6790)
  • 93f8f13 chore(deps): update github/codeql-action action to v3.28.18 (#6789)
  • 1556ff2 chore(deps): update codecov/codecov-action action to v5.4.3 (#6785)

Updates `go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlpmetric/otlpmetrichttp` from 1.34.0 to 1.36.0
Changelog

Sourced from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlpmetric/otlpmetrichttp's changelog.

[1.36.0/0.58.0/0.12.0] 2025-05-20

Added

  • Add exponential histogram support in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6421)
  • The go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.31.0 package. The package contains semantic conventions from the v1.31.0 version of the OpenTelemetry Semantic Conventions. See the migration documentation for information on how to upgrade from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.30.0. (#6479)
  • Add Recording, Scope, and Record types in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6507)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlptrace/otlptracehttp. (#6751)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlpmetric/otlpmetrichttp. (#6752)
  • Add WithHTTPClient option to configure the http.Client used by go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploghttp. (#6688)
  • Add ValuesGetter in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation, a TextMapCarrier that supports retrieving multiple values for a single key. (#5973)
  • Add Values method to HeaderCarrier to implement the new ValuesGetter interface in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation. (#5973)
  • Update Baggage in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/propagation to retrieve multiple values for a key when the carrier implements ValuesGetter. (#5973)
  • Add AssertEqual function in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6662)
  • The go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.32.0 package. The package contains semantic conventions from the v1.32.0 version of the OpenTelemetry Semantic Conventions. See the migration documentation for information on how to upgrade from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/semconv/v1.31.0(#6782)
  • Add Transform option in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6794)
  • Add Desc option in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6796)

Removed

  • Drop support for [Go 1.22]. (#6381, #6418)
  • Remove Resource field from EnabledParameters in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log. (#6494)
  • Remove RecordFactory type from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6492)
  • Remove ScopeRecords, EmittedRecord, and RecordFactory types from go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest. (#6507)
  • Remove AssertRecordEqual function in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest, use AssertEqual instead. (#6662)

Changed

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Update github.com/prometheus/client_golang to v1.21.1, which changes the NameValidationScheme to UTF8Validation. This allows metrics names to keep original delimiters (e.g. .), rather than replacing with underscores. This can be reverted by setting github.com/prometheus/common/model.NameValidationScheme to LegacyValidation in github.com/prometheus/common/model. (#6433)
  • Initialize map with len(keys) in NewAllowKeysFilter and NewDenyKeysFilter to avoid unnecessary allocations in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/attribute. (#6455)
  • go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest is now a separate Go module. (#6465)
  • go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log/logtest is now a separate Go module. (#6466)
  • Recorder in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/log/logtest no longer separately stores records emitted by loggers with the same instrumentation scope. (#6507)
  • Improve performance of BatchProcessor in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/sdk/log by not exporting when exporter cannot accept more. (#6569, #6641)

Deprecated

  • Deprecate support for model.LegacyValidation for go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6449)

Fixes

  • Stop percent encoding header environment variables in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploggrpc and go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/otlp/otlplog/otlploghttp. (#6392)
  • Ensure the noopSpan.tracerProvider method is not inlined in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/trace so the go.opentelemetry.io/auto instrumentation can instrument non-recording spans. (#6456)
  • Use a sync.Pool instead of allocating metricdata.ResourceMetrics in go.opentelemetry.io/otel/exporters/prometheus. (#6472)

... (truncated)

milestone.title: üöÄ Mainnet beta launch
milestone.description:
**Main Milestone - We're On It! üöß**

Hey all! We're right in the thick of our "main" milestone. It's not just a label; it's the heart of what we're currently pouring our energies into. And, let's be honest, it's both exciting and challenging at the same time!

üôå **Here's how you can jump in:**
1. Take a peek at the open issues and PRs tied to this milestone.
2. Got an idea, a hunch, or even a gut feeling? Share it! Every perspective counts.
3. Chime into the discussions. The more, the merrier, and two heads (or ten) are always better than one.

This milestone is a journey, and every bit of effort, feedback, and camaraderie counts. Let's roll up our sleeves, maybe grab some coffee (or tea!), and push through this together. Cheers to making progress! üéâ

body:
## Requirement

https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4143

## Description

- The setting system parameters API is designed to set the full list of parameters as a slice. To update the unrestricted accounts list, we implemented separate add and remove proposal requests to update the status of individual accounts instead of setting the entire list every time an update is needed.
- Added logic to update the status of accounts in auth keeper auth.WillSetParams() upon parameter changes.
- Added GetSystemParams method in sys/params
- Added full-cycle integration tests to update the unrestricted account status from GovDAO.

title: META gnomod.toml
body:
The foundation for `gnomod.toml` is done in [#4331](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4331).

It gives us structured package-level. This metadata will let us control visibility, running constraints, versioning(?), and usage policies for packages. It‚Äôs especially urgent for cleaning up the examples/ folder ahead of launch.

Needed now:

To proceed with examples/ cleanup for launch, we need to implement `private` and `draft` flags (https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4370):
- `draft=true`: can be deployed at genesis, but not with addpkg, can be imported by other genesis packages, but not by newly added one
- `private=`true`: cannot be imported or state-persisted externally

Can be done later
- Support `upload_metadata.uploader` in lazy genesis for use with std.PrevRealm in init(). (https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4371)
- Port/fix `gno mod graph` to work after #4331
- Add `replace` directive support (https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/2601)
- Consider versioning/deprecation fields
- Improve `gnoweb` display based on package metadata
- Improve docs/supports/examples
- Completely deprecate previous `gno.mod` file after a grace period
- Refactor `pkg/gnomod` to remove the previous `xxx_pkg.go part of the package
- Consider other fields (see https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/498)
- Support comments and arbitrary order (currently replaced when remarshaling)

Related
https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/2904

title: RFC(grc20): standardizing token precision

milestone.title: ‚è≠Ô∏èNext after mainnet beta
milestone.description: Issues and PRs that we'd love to tackle after the gno.land mainnet is launched.

body:
We need to decide whether GRC20 tokens should use int64 (64-bit) or uint256 (256-bit).

Context
- GnoVM and `std.Coin` use `int64`, including gas and bank logic.
- Gnoswap is the only contract using `uint256`, and only temporarily, for Uniswap ported math. It still stores values as int64.

Options

1. Use `int64` (my preference)
- Fully compatible with Gno‚Äôs native coin system
- Follows [token philosophy](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/master/PHILOSOPHY.md#token-philosophy)
- Keeps the ecosystem simpler
- We can provide a helper lib (e.g. `p/tokeninterop`) for interop with 256-bit systems

2. Use `uint256`
- Matches Uniswap-style math, and increase native compatibility with other ecosystems
- Adds complexity, type conversions, and risks

3. Support both
- Define `grc20` and `grc20u256` (question: how to name them?)
- Adds flexibility, but splits ecosystem and increases maintenance

Future with Gno2

Gno2 could support native `uint256` types (compiling to `big.Int` or something else), making dual precision cleaner in the long term.

Let‚Äôs agree on a direction so future contracts have clear guidance.
I‚Äôm in favor of sticking with `int64`, and helping with optional interop libraries.

cc @gnolang/onbloc

title: test(proof): add failing case

labels.name: :package: :globe_with_meridians:  tendermint v2
labels.description: Issues or PRs tm2 related

body:
Following convo on Signal, I create this draft PR to demonstrate the bug and report all the informations.

# Disclaimer

I didn't test all the different scenarios so there might be other cases of proof generation that are incorrect. The case I present here is the one I had a chance to reproduce, but I found an other scenario where the proof was also incorrect but differently than the case here. 

# Context 

While I was asserting the behavior of tm2 proofs (for the IBC connection with A1), and I found an issue with absence proofs. 

The test `TestTreeGetWithProof()` (modified in this PR) builds a merkle tree with keys `0x11, 0x32, 0x50, 0x72, 0x99`, and so looks like this:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2591f9b3-4016-413f-a0ab-b852667166be)

- *Node label is `KEY / HASH`*
- *The first two leafs are numbered with 1 and 2 for the  purpose of the demo.*

After asserting a proof of the presence of the key `0x32`, which is not relevant here, the test asserts a proof of the absence of key `0x1`.  The returned proof is correct and asserts that `0x1` is absent of the tree. In term of leaves, the proof contains only the leaf 1, because `0x1 < 0x11` (key of 1).

Now if that key is changed to `0x1100` like in this PR, the  returned proof is exactly the same as with `0x1`, but this is incorrect because this time `0x1100 > 0x11`. For that proof to be correct, the proof's leaves should contain both 1 and 2 because `0x1100` is between `0x11` and `0x32`.

Hence the verification algorithm returns an error, given that absence of second leaf: `absence not proved by right leaf (need another leaf?)`

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Part of https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4365.

We want to extend gnomod.toml metadata to support two new flags to control package usage constraints:

Goals
- Rename existing `draft=true` ‚Üí `ignore=true`. Used to skip packages in tools like `./...` or genesis lazy scans, while keeping them directly usable in development environments.
- Add `draft=true`. Can be deployed at genesis, and imported by other genesis packages, but not added or imported later. For bundling pre-release dapps with user-only public-facing. Allowed for both `p/`, and `r/`.
- Add `private=true`. Disallows imports and state persistence by other packages. Only allowed for `r/`, not for `p/`. Useful for building isolated, swappable contracts like `r/<ns>/home`.

Tasks
- update the `gnovm/pkg/gnomod.File` fields
- update the `gno.land/pkg/sdk/vm.AddPackage` import logic
- update the `gnovm/pkg/gnolang` ownership logic

This is a key step toward launch so we can clean up and lock down `examples/`.

This task is a great opportunity for someone who wants to contribute to the VM internals for the first time. Ping @mvertes, @ltzmaxwell, or @thehowl if you want to tackle this or need guidance.

title: support upload_metadata.uploader in lazy genesis for correct init() behavior

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Part of https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4365.

We need to support the `upload_metadata.uploader` field during genesis uploads, specifically in `examples/`, to allow setting an arbitrary package author during the actual AddPackage.

This allows func `init()` to run under the expected identity (e.g., `std.OriginCaller()`, `std.PrevRealm()` or `cur realm`), preserving correct initialization logic such as setting a contract owner.

What to do:
- In `gno.land/pkg/gnoland.LoadPackage(...)` (https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/master/gno.land/pkg/gnoland/genesis.go#L209-L230), read `mpkg.UploadMetadata.Uploader` (if present).
- Use this value instead of the provided `creator bft.Address` when building the `MsgAddPackage` message.

title: Serve homepage from local .md using --alias=/ and dynamic sync from r/gnoland/home
body:
Note: I remember writing about a similar issue, but I can't find it anymore. If anyone finds it, please feel free to share the link.

Use `--alias=/=./home.md` (feature by @aeddi) for the homepage, synced from `r/gnoland/home`.
This avoids bricked contracts, supports overrides, and makes updates safer.

## Plan

1. write this script
```sh
# misc/deployments/update-home.sh

# if this file exists, it means we want to bypass the script behavior and just manage the homepage manually.
if [ -f home-override.md ]; then
  cp home-override.md home.md
  exit 0
fi

# tries to query r/gnoland/home.
if gnokey query ... > out.md; then
  # eventually patch the page to add things like the newsletter html form
  echo "<!-- extra blocks -->" >> out.md
  mv out.md home.md
else
  echo "warn: failed to update"
fi
```

2. configure docker-compose/kube to periodically run this script

3. configure docker-compose/kube to use the `--alias=/:./home.md`

title: [gnoweb] User template render for any /u/ input - missing existence check and fallback to 404
body:
## Description

Currently, any URL matching the /u/username pattern renders a user page, regardless of whether the user actually exists. For example, accessing /u/nonsense-user still renders a user profile template instead of a 404.

To improve this behavior, we should verify the existence of the user before rendering the page. The user registry is stored in r/sys/users, but this does not include genesis-reserved usernames, which leads to an incomplete check.

The desired outcome would be:

- Only valid usernames render the /u/ page.
- Invalid or non-existent users should return a clean 404.
- Genesis users should be handled properly without false negatives.

### questions

- how should we handle genesis-reserved usernames that are not present in r/sys/registry?
- Should we introduce a static whitelist in gnoweb for these genesis users?
- Would it be possible (or better) to extend the registry itself to include them?
- Once the existence check is implemented, we should render a proper 404 page when the user does not exist.

Cc @leohhhn

title: feat(cmd/gno): `fix` subcommand

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

body:
This is a re-implementation of #4100, which uses the same framework it introduces and adapts the current transpiler (for gno 0.9) to it.

This is an alternative approach, that instead of being based on the Gno AST, it works with the Go AST and thus is able to reach similar objectives with less code.

This [gist](https://gist.github.com/thehowl/bd209e297efbc976409f2f493f703748) shows the difference between the state of `examples` in 62a16f038, and what is generated by `gno fix -fix interrealm` instead.

The transpiler leaves code in a state where it likely still need fixes; mostly because crossing functions change signatures, but their usage is not updated if the caller did not use `cross()`, which can happen for calls within the same package. All of the errors printed by `gno lint` afterwards are about too many or too few arguments passed to functions.

Why we should go with an AST analysis instead of the transpiler on master:

- The AST type checker is faster, and simpler to write more fixes for.
- It doesn't require types to make sense, and thus doesn't require a complete understanding of how Gno used to work in a previous version (unless the syntax of the language changes)

I decided to rewrite the 0.9 transpiler because most of what needed to be transpiled had to be transpiled anyway, and I believe the approach in this PR is cleaner over the long term.

title: feat(gnovm): Add Debug Adapter Protocol (DAP) Support to Gno Debugger

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

labels.name: review/triage-pending
labels.description: PRs opened by external contributors that are waiting for the 1st review

body:
# Description

This PR implements Debug Adapter Protocol (DAP)[^1] support for the Gno debugger, enabling integration with IDEs and editors like VS Code, Neovim, Zed[^2] and others that support DAP.

Ultimately, since DAP is not a core function, it would be better to extract it as an external project. For this work, it seems that adding an interface to enable the debugger to communicate with external systems should be prioritized first.

And of course, this feature alone cannot directly connect the debugger to an external IDE, and an appropriate extension must be implemented. This PR only handles the work of passing the necessary data to extensions that will be implemented in future.

## What is DAP?

The DAP is a standardized protocol that defines the communication beween dev tools and debuggers. By implementing DAP, the Gno debbuger can now work with any IDE that supports this protocol without requiring custom integrations.

## Usage

To use DAP module:

```bash
gno run --debug-addr=localhost:9090 --dap <file.gno>
```

### Testing

To test with python scripts, start DAP server first:

```bash
gno run --debug-addr localhost:2345 --dap gnovm/tests/integ/debugger/test_struct.gno &
```

Once the DAP server is ready, run the script (path: `gnovm/tests/integ/dap`) you want to run. For example:

```bash
python3 gnovm/tests/integ/dap/test_dap_variables.py
```

**Output**

```plain
Connected to DAP server

‚Üí initialize
‚Üê Initialize: True
‚Üí launch
‚Üê Launch: True
‚Üí setBreakpoints
‚Üê Event: initialized
‚Üê SetBreakpoints: True
‚Üí configurationDone
‚Üí continue
‚Üí threads
‚Üê Event: continued
‚Üê Event: stopped
‚Üí stackTrace

Frame ID: 0
‚Üí scopes

Getting variables for scope: Locals
‚Üí variables

Local Variables:
  p = (struct{("Alice" string),(30 int),(slice[("developer" string),("gopher" string)] []string)} main.Person) (main.Person) [ref=3000]
    Expanding p...
‚Üí variables
      Name = ("Alice" string) (string)
      Age = (30 int) (int)
      Tags = []string (length=2, cap=2) ([]string)
‚Üí disconnect

Disconnected
```

## Breaking Changes

None. The existing debugger interface remains unchanged. DAP support is opt-in via the `--dap` flag.

## Implemented Features

### Core DAP Support

- **DAP Server Implementation**: Added `DAPServer` struct that handles DAP protocol communication over TCP
- **Concurrent Execution Model**: Program runs in a separate goroutine while DAP server controls execution
- **Message Handling**: Full implementation of DAP request/response/event message processing

### Debugging Capabilities

#### Breakpoint Management
- **Enhanced Breakpoint Matching**: Fixed and improved breakpoint matching logic to handle various file path formats
- **Path Matching**: Supports exact path, basename, and relative path suffix matching
- **Stopped Events**: Properly sends stopped events when breakpoints are hit

#### Variable Inspection
- **Complex Type Expansion**: Full support for expanding arrays, slices, structs, and maps in IDE variable views
- **HeapItemValue Handling**: Automatically unwraps heap-allocated values for proper display
- **DeclaredType Support**: Handles custom types (e.g., `type Person struct{...}`) with proper field expansion
- **Variable References**: Implements DAP variable reference system for nested data exploration

#### Program Control
- **Execution Control**: Support for continue, step in, step over, and step out operations
- **Automatic Execution**: Programs without breakpoints run automatically after configuration
- **Termination Handling**: Sends proper terminated events when program execution completes

#### Output Redirection
- **Console Output**: All program output (`println`, etc.) is redirected to IDE debug console via DAP output events
- **Output Categories**: Properly categorizes output as stdout for IDE console display

[^1]: DAP speficications https://microsoft.github.io/debug-adapter-protocol//
[^2]: DAP support has recently been added to Zed. https://zed.dev/blog/debugger

title: gnovm: panic on invoking stored callback

labels.name: üêû bug

body:
### Description
Invoking any callback passed into `run` (even an empty `func() {}`) causes a nil‚Äëpointer panic in the Gno VM‚Äôs (during the `op_call` instruction). 


### Steps to reproduce

```
adduserfrom member 'success myself purchase tray reject demise scene little legend someone lunar hope media goat regular test area smart save flee surround attack rapid smoke'
stdout 'g1c0j899h88nwyvnzvh5jagpq6fkkyuj76nld6t0'

# load specific govDAO implementation and needed users for your integration test
loadpkg gno.land/r/demo/executor $WORK/executor

gnoland start


gnokey maketx run -gas-fee 1000000ugnot -gas-wanted 100000000 -broadcast -chainid=tendermint_test member $WORK/setter/main.gno
stdout OK!

gnokey maketx call -pkgpath gno.land/r/demo/executor -func Execute -gas-fee 1000000ugnot -gas-wanted 10000000 -broadcast -chainid=tendermint_test member
stdout OK!


-- setter/main.gno --
package main

import (
	"gno.land/r/demo/executor"
)

func main() {
```

body:
Various improvements:

1. Quick win: Only GovDAO members can submit proposals. #4434
2. When we call `e := dao.NewSimpleExecutor(cb, "")`, the `NewSimpleExecutor` should store its `prevrealm.PkgAddr` and display it when we list proposals. This way, we can expect people to use `maketx run` to craft proposals, while executors are managed by `r/` persistent contracts.
3. @gfanton should update us on the current state of the JSON PR. This will enable querying an object value and allow gnoweb to inline query any object, letting us preview the content of a variable. Once this feature is implemented, the govdao should simplify checking the value, similar to the `txlink` pattern but for queries, perhaps called `querylink`.


Related https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/4424
Related https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4426#pullrequestreview-2961950674

title: Make MsgCall error more descriptive in case of crossing
body:
## Description

All funcs meant to be called directly with MsgCall must be crossing. This means:
1) Exported but non crossing funcs should always be called with a `qeval`; ie getters
2) If a func is called with MsgCall but it does not have the first argument of type realm, the response error message to the user should be along the lines of `{funcName} cannot be called with MsgCall (/directly). It can either be called with qeval, or via another code realm`.

Currently, the keeper spews an error that doesn't make sense to the end-user.

```
gnokey maketx call -pkgpath "gno.land/r/demo/emit" -func "Emit" -args "" -gas-fee 100000
0ugnot -gas-wanted 5000000 -send "" -broadcast -chainid "staging" -remote "https://rpc.gno
```

title: Proposal: Post-Execution Gas Payment in Gno
body:
### Summary

This proposal explores adding support for **postpaid gas**  only requiring payment **after** successful execution. This would enable dynamic contract-sponsored gas payments, reduce onboarding friction, and create a cleaner developer and user experience without third-party infrastructure.

---

### Motivation

Currently, Gno.land follows the conventional model where users must prepay gas before a transaction is executed. While this protects the network, it also introduces the following limitations:

- Requires users to acquire and hold GNOT before using any app.
- Prevents contracts from funding or sponsoring users during execution.
- Creates UX friction, especially for onboarding.

This proposal challenges the need for pre-execution gas checks and explores a system where gas is enforced **after execution**, based on the final state.

---

### How It Works

1. A user submits a transaction without needing GNOT upfront.
2. During execution, a contract may transfer GNOT to the user (e.g., a reward, sponsorship, or faucet).
3. After execution:
   - The node checks if the sender now holds enough GNOT to cover gas.
   - If so, gas is deducted and the transaction is accepted.
   - If not, the transaction is reverted or rejected.

This enables the contract itself to act as a sponsor or funder.

---

### DoS and Abuse Considerations

A common objection is that this would increase DoS risk. But prepaid gas doesn't eliminate DoS ‚Äî attackers can still fund malicious contracts and submit spammy, expensive transactions.

Under this proposal:

- Gas is still tracked during execution.
- Per-account or per-block limits can be enforced.

---

### Delegation and Sponsorship

This model naturally supports:

- Contract-sponsored gas.
- DAO-funded transactions.
- "tx free" or freemium experiences.
- Developer-paid UX (where the dApp funds user activity behind the scenes).

---

### Comparison to Existing Models

| Feature                            | Postpaid in Gno                        | ERC‚Äë4337 (Account Abstraction)           | Meta-Transactions (EIP‚Äë2771)             |
|------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| When is gas paid?                 | After execution                        | Before execution via Paymaster           | Before execution (by relayer)            |
| Who pays gas?                     | Sender (after being funded)            | Paymaster contract                        | Relayer                                   |
| Needs third party?                | No                                     | Yes (Bundler + Paymaster)                | Yes (Relayer + Forwarder)                |
| Requires VM change?              | Yes                         | No                                       | No                                       |
| Use case focus                   | Contract-sponsored UX                  | Wallet abstraction                       | DApp onboarding                           |

Unlike ERC‚Äë4337 or meta-transactions, this model does not depend on external relayers or paymasters. It places the responsibility and flexibility within the contract logic itself.

---


### Why can‚Äôt we do this?

Why can‚Äôt we:
- Allow contracts to sponsor users?
- Let users receive GNOT mid-execution?
- Move gas enforcement from pre-execution to post-execution?
- Create a chain that is gasless by default?

**If nothing fundamental prevents it‚Ä¶ why can‚Äôt we do it?**

title: [gnoweb] proposal: gno-button feature
body:
Why buttons ?

So right now, any actions are made using text link. But sometimes, i's not really intuitive, or maybe it's not really looking great, for example if you have a "Submit" action, i think it should be better to use a button rather than clicking on a text link.

### How will it look like

For example, here is what gno.land discord link looks like right now:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7b0c2f5c-c966-490b-8506-b2b53cd4df18)

And this is how it can render using a button:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/662fd944-0c9b-45b0-a79a-3aec4f70bf4a)

---

Another example, with browse in the main gno.land page. Right now, it looks like this:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c3f1c65f-1518-441c-88f0-a42ac6f97e0b)

Here is how can it be rendered using buttons instead:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a6ffc714-a269-4cae-aaf1-8727e9777ae3)

And i personnally think it's a cleaner and more intuitive way to have the buttons

---

The idea is not to replace everything by buttons, but having this feature can improve the user experience in my oppinion.

### How will it look like in the code
```
<gno-button link=":here?value=true">
  Hello
</gno-button>
```
and inside, it should support markdown, so we can just do
```
<gno-button>
  ## This is H2 text
</gno-button>
```

The idea is then to integrate it in `p/moul/md`, so developpers can use the API
```go
import "gno.land/p/moul/md"

func Render(_ string) string {
  // render with text
  btnWithText := md.Button("rickroll", "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQw4w9WgXcQ")

  // render a H1 Text
  btnWithBigText := md.Button(md.H1("Submit"), ":submit")

  // render with svg
  myCanvas := svg.NewCanvas(100, 100)
  // ... do cool stuff with svg here, like drawing the gno logo
  btnWithGnoHead := md.Button(myCanvas.Render(), "https://gno.land")
}
```
What do you guys think ? is it a good feature to implement ? I don't think it would be hard to implement but i think it could really improve UX on gno

body: This PR adds a markdown extension that allows creating buttons with two different syntaxes:: ## Supported Syntaxes - **Shorthand markdown syntax:** `{Label | options}(url)` - **HTML syntax:** `Label` ## Supported Variants - `outline` - `caution` - `warning` - `info` - `note` - (combinable, e.g. `caution outline`) ### Features and updates - Both syntaxes render as `` tags with appropriate classes for styling. - Variants are validated against a whitelist. - The `plain` option has been removed; the default button is now the fallback. - Outline buttons have border colors matching their variant and no background. - The HTML `` syntax supports the `variant` attribute for all variants. - All logic is covered by golden file tests. - Documentation and user examples have been updated.

body:
## Description

This PR does two things: it renames `p/leon/coinsort` into `p/leon/coinutils`, adds a `CoinFromString` & `CoinsFromString` functions, and uses them in `p/moul/txlink` to check if the added send value is `>=0`.

The change in txlink is because it does not make sense for a txlink to contain negative or zero coin amounts. `gnokey` even panics because it cannot parse the coin string, ie with:


title: feat(txtar): txtar file options & formating

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

labels.name: :package: :mountain:  gno.land
labels.description: Issues or PRs gno.land package related

body:
I initially aimed to resolve timeout issue caused by a potential process leak when a node was not ready, which led to test failures. The process could persist because it was not terminated.

I've ended adding a way to customize the test runtime on a file-by-file basis using flag options with `# txtar:opts <flags>` at the beginning of the file.

```
-no-fmt
     Disable formatting of Gno files in this test file. Use this to preserve original formatting.

-no-parallel
     Disable parallel execution for this test file. This is handled natively using t.Parallel.

-skip
     Skip this test file entirely.

-timeout <duration>
     Set a custom timeout for this test file (e.g., -timeout 90s).
```

e.g with `gc.txtar` file:
![Screenshot 2025-07-10 at 12 14 46](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/69fe382b-8d48-423e-a4e1-76990f040982)

You can find more infos in `doc.go` within integration folder.

This feature also enables an easy and convenient way to integrate more options in the future at either the file or test level.

### Note

- `-no-parallel` flag override previous implementation by doing it natively using `t.Parallel` instead of mutex locking.
- `-timeout` can be set either at file flags level (global file timeout), or at node level using `gnoland start -timeout=x`

### Formatting

I also added a way to format `gno` files within `txtar`. You can use it with `go test -ts-fmt` (files using `-no-fmt` option will not be formated). This formatting is not yet enforced in the CI, as it can be somewhat inconvenient to run. It requires a test to be fully complete and the package to be loaded in memory to resolve and format the file. While it should be possible to enforce this, I will add it to the CI later.

this PR include formatting on some `txtar` files

When executing the code snippet below, a runtime panic occurs in the Gno VM:

```golang
package main

import "strconv"

type stringMap map[*int]int

var (
    a        int = 1
    accounts     = stringMap{}
    ptr          = &a
)

func Register() {
    accounts[ptr] = 1
    accounts[nil] = 1
}

func main() {
    Register()
}
```

Hey all! We're right in the thick of our "main" milestone. It's not just a label; it's the heart of what we're currently pouring our energies into. And, let's be honest, it's both exciting and challenging at the same time!

üôå **Here's how you can jump in:**
1. Take a peek at the open issues and PRs tied to this milestone.
2. Got an idea, a hunch, or even a gut feeling? Share it! Every perspective counts.
3. Chime into the discussions. The more, the merrier, and two heads (or ten) are always better than one.

This milestone is a journey, and every bit of effort, feedback, and camaraderie counts. Let's roll up our sleeves, maybe grab some coffee (or tea!), and push through this together. Cheers to making progress! üéâ

title: perf(crypto/keys/armor): do not hash with empty passphrase

labels.name: :package: :globe_with_meridians:  tendermint v2
labels.description: Issues or PRs tm2 related

body:
This PR changes the crypto/keys/armor behaviour, and hence gnokey, to bypass encryption entirely when no passphrase is given.

This helps to speed up txtar tests, and helps in local development for cases where you have keys like test1 that you don't typically save with a password.

These changes maintain backward compatibility, including a test, to ensure that old keys with an empty password can still be used.

I changed the behaviour of `gnokey` for commands which had the `-unsafe` option: to use an unencrypted key, just pass in no password.

title: fix(gnovm): Handle nil `fBlocksMap` in cached packages

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

body:
# Description

The `GetPackage` method in `store.go` was returning cached packages without ensuring that their `fBlocksMap` was properly initialized. When a package was retrieved from cache, it could have a `nil` `fBlocksMap`, leading to runtime panics when trying to access file blocks.

To fix this, we added a simple nil check and initialization in the `GetPackage` method.

## Problem

During package deployment, we encountered a _"file block missing"_ error that cause the problem in deployment of packages. The error as follows:

```plain
file block missing for file "pool_type.gno"
```

This error occurred when the VM attempted to access file blocks from a cached package whose `fBlocksMap` field was `nil`. I assume that the issue was particularly problematic in complex package import scenarios, such as those found in the gnoswap project where multiple packages with numerous files are interdependent.

## Testing

- `TestGetPackageWithNilFBlocksMap`: Simulates the bug scenario with multi-file packages
- `TestGetPackageFromCacheMultipleTimes`: Ensures repeated access to cached packages works correctly

## Production Verification

Since applying this patch in commit [5dbda84](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/commit/5dbda8429fa832ca5f1b35334c09a2906c7a77a4), the "file block missing" error has not recurred in internal deployments. (Note: failed to cherry-pick due to the divergence)

title: BasicNFT and basicGRC1155Token struct types should be exported (capitalized) for external package access
body:
## Description

The core struct types basicNFT and basicGRC1155Token in the GRC721 and GRC1155 implementations are currently defined with lowercase names, making them inaccessible from external packages. This prevents other contracts from properly importing and using these fundamental NFT types.

Current Problem
The following core struct types are unexported (lowercase):
GRC721 Package:

```
// examples/gno.land/p/demo/grc/grc721/basic_nft.gno
type basicNFT struct {
    name              string
    symbol            string
    owners            avl.Tree // tokenId -> OwnerAddress
    balances          avl.Tree // OwnerAddress -> TokenCount
    tokenApprovals    avl.Tree // TokenId -> ApprovedAddress
    tokenURIs         avl.Tree // TokenId -> URIs
    operatorApprovals avl.Tree // "OwnerAddress:OperatorAddress" -> bool
}
```

GRC1155 Package:
```
// examples/gno.land/p/demo/grc/grc1155/basic_grc1155_token.gno
type basicGRC1155Token struct {
    uri               string
    balances          avl.Tree // "TokenId:Address" -> int64
    operatorApprovals avl.Tree // "OwnerAddress:OperatorAddress" -> bool
}
```

Expected Behavior
These core struct types should be exported (capitalized) to allow external packages to use them:

```
// Expected implementation
type BasicNFT struct { ... }
type BasicGRC1155Token struct { ... }
```

### Impact

* Other contracts cannot import and use these fundamental NFT struct types directly
* Prevents proper type checking and compilation when other packages try to reference these types
* Limits the reusability and interoperability of the GRC721 and GRC1155 implementations
* Forces developers to work around the unexported types or duplicate functionality
* These are the core/base types that other NFT implementations (like metadataNFT, royaltyNFT) embed, so making them unexported severely limits extensibility

### Suggested Solution

* Rename basicNFT to BasicNFT
* Rename basicGRC1155Token to BasicGRC1155Token

title: `package_test` produces a unexpected circular dependency error

labels.name: üêû bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
## Unexpected circular dependency error with `package_test`

### Description

The issue occurs when using a test package located in the same directory as the package to be tested, with the name simply suffixed by `_test`:
- a package `importee` is imported by a package `importer`
- a package `importee_test` is located in the same directory as `importee`
- `importee_test` imports the package `importer`

The following error occurs when starting the node: `unable to load examples folder: sorting packages: cycle detected: gno.land/r/issue/importee`.

### Your environment

* Go version: go1.24.1
* OS and CPU architecture: darwin/arm64
* Gno commit hash causing the issue: 34ba1efdb4fe0e23183a3524ff306a0429de9928

### Steps to reproduce

#### Using a gnolang node

1. Create the files below 
2. Run `gnolang start --lazy`
<details><summary>Files</summary>

#### `examples/gno.land/r/issue/importer/gnomod.toml`
```toml
module = "gno.land/r/issue/importer"
gno = "0.9"
```

#### `examples/gno.land/r/issue/importer/importer.gno`
```go
package importer

import (
	"gno.land/r/issue/importee"
)

func Function() {
	importee.Function()
}
```

#### `examples/gno.land/r/issue/importee/gnomod.toml`
```toml
module = "gno.land/r/issue/importee"
gno = "0.9"
```

#### `examples/gno.land/r/issue/importee/importee.gno`
```go
package importee

func Function() {}
```

#### `examples/gno.land/r/issue/importee/importee_test.gno`
```go
package importee_test

import (
	"testing"

	"gno.land/r/issue/importee"
	"gno.land/r/issue/importer" // <- this import will be considered circular
)

func TestFunction(_ *testing.T) {
	importee.Function()
	importer.Function()
}
```

</details> 


#### Using a txtar

1. Create the txtar below 
2. Run `cd gno.land/pkg/integration && go test -v -run=TestTestdata/issue_xxx`
<details><summary>File</summary>

#### `gno.land/pkg/integration/testdata/issue_xxx.txtar`
```
# Load packages from $WORK directory.
loadpkg gno.land/r/issue/importee $WORK/importee
loadpkg gno.land/r/issue/importer $WORK/importer

# Start the node
gnoland start
stdout 'node started successfully'

-- importer/gnomod.toml --
module = "gno.land/r/issue/importer"
gno = "0.9"

-- importer/importer.gno --
package importer

import (
	"gno.land/r/issue/importee"
)

func Function() {
	importee.Function()
}

-- importee/gnomod.toml --
module = "gno.land/r/issue/importee"
gno = "0.9"

-- importee/importee.gno --
package importee

func Function() {}

-- importee/importee_test.gno --
package importee_test

import (
	"testing"

	"gno.land/r/issue/importee"
	"gno.land/r/issue/importer" // <- this import will be produce an error
)

func TestFunction(_ *testing.T) {
	importee.Function()
	importer.Function()
}
```

</details> 

### Expected behaviour

Neither of these two cases should produce an error.

### Actual behaviour

#### Using a gnolang node

The node produce this error: `sorting packages: cycle detected: gno.land/r/issue/importee`

#### Using a txtar

The error is slightly different in this case: `invalid gno package; type check errors:\ngno.land/r/issue/importee/importee_test.gno:7:2: could not import gno.land/r/issue/importer (unknown import path "gno.land/r/issue/importer")`

### Logs

<details><summary>Full gnolang node logs</summary>

```
gno.land % gnoland start --lazy
Default configuration initialized at /Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/config/config.toml
WARN: Initialized default node config at "/Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/config"

Validator private key saved at /Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/secrets/priv_validator_key.json
Validator last sign state saved at /Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/secrets/priv_validator_state.json
Node key saved at /Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/secrets/node_key.json
WARN: Initialized default node secrets at "/Users/aeddi/Code/gno/gno.land/gnoland-data/secrets"
unable to initialize genesis.json, unable to generate genesis file, unable to load examples folder: sorting packages: cycle detected: gno.land/r/issue/importee
```

</details> 

<details><summary>Full txtar logs</summary>

```
integration % go test -v -run=TestTestdata/issue_xxx
=== RUN   TestTestdata
=== PAUSE TestTestdata
=== CONT  TestTestdata
=== RUN   TestTestdata/issue_xxx
=== PAUSE TestTestdata/issue_xxx
```

title: add 'inherit' permission to gnomod.toml vocab
body:
## Description
Inheritable Permissions on Gno.land (with gnomod.toml)

By adding an inherit option for module-level permissions‚Äîconfigured in the new gnomod.toml at the root of a realm/module‚Äîwe promote access control to a higher level set of contorls.

# gnomod.toml
```
module = "gno.land/r/stackdump000"
private = true
```

```
module = "gno.land/r/stackdump000/subrealm"
inherit = true
```
‚Äì /r/stackdump000 is set to private
‚Äì /r/stackdump000/subrealm/ declares inherit, meaning it doesn‚Äôt override but follows the parent‚Äôs rules.
‚Äì All writes are restricted by the parent realm and must originate from within its hierarchy.

This moves realm-based permissions up a level, enabling parent realms to delegate and enforce write access without exposing global permissions.


## Current solution
This could replace the current pattern I'm using in a few places

```
func init() {
	realmAllowPrefix = append(realmAllowPrefix, std.CurrentRealm().PkgPath()+"/patch")
}
```

```
func hasAllowedPrefix() bool {
	currentRealm := std.CurrentRealm()
	for _, callerPath := range realmAllowPrefix {
		if strings.HasPrefix(currentRealm.PkgPath(), callerPath) {
			return true
		}
	}
	return false
}
```

title: gnodev: Issues with PreLoading, Lazy Loading, Proxy Parsing and more
body:
## Setup Context

We are working on the [Volos](https://github.com/gnoverse/volos) lending protocol using [Gnoswap](https://github.com/gnoswap-labs/gnoswap) for price feed, so our development environment is the Gno monorepo with all the Gnoswap packages included.

## Issues Encountered

### 1. ~~Inconsistent package detection with wildcard paths~~ (Skip this section as the [latest commit](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/commit/8bd65def180ea9b43e59b2b89c2894c8f76ed6fb) somehow fixed the issue)

Some packages aren't detected for preloading when using wildcard paths like `gno.land/r/gnoswap/**`. For example, while most subpackages load correctly, `gno.land/r/gnoswap/v1/position` and `gno.land/r/gnoswap/v1/test_tokens/**` must be explicitly included for  them to be recognized for preloading.

So command for properly preloading all the [Gnoswap packages](https://github.com/gnoswap-labs/gnoswap/tree/main/contract/r/gnoswap) would look like
```
gnodev -paths "gno.land/r/gnoswap/**,gno.land/r/gnoswap/v1/position,gno.land/r/gnoswap/v1/test_tokens/**"
```

### 2. Lazy loading causes timeouts

The lazy loader doesn‚Äôt always preload required packages in time. If a transaction depends on a larger package that hasn‚Äôt been loaded yet, the first call will fail due to a timeout. A second attempt will succeed because the package gets loaded during the initial failed call. The error logs were very misleading, so it took me a while to figure out what was actually wrong.

Error log:
```--= Error =--
Data: unauthorized error
Msg Traces:
    0  /Users/stefann/GithubProjects/gno/tm2/pkg/errors/errors.go:28 - check transaction failed: log:--= Error =--
Data: std.UnauthorizedError{abciError:std.abciError{}}
Msg Traces:
    0  /Users/stefann/GithubProjects/gno/tm2/pkg/std/errors.go:72 - signature verification failed; verify correct account, sequence, and chain-id
```
### 3. Proxy misparses query function calls as package paths

The proxy incorrectly treating `vm/qeval` function calls as full package paths. For example, it tries to resolve `gno.land/r/volos.GetPositionSupplyShares("gno.land/r/demo/wugnot` as if it's a package path.

Query command:
```
gnokey query vm/qeval -remote $(GNOLAND_RPC_URL) -data "gno.land/r/volos.GetPositionSupplyShares(\"gno.land/r/demo/wugnot:gno.land/r/gnoswap/v1/test_token/bar:3000\", \"$(ADMIN)\")"
```

Logs:
```
Loader      ‚îÉ W package not found resolver=root<gno>/root<examples> path="gno.land/r/volos.GetPositionSupplyShares(\"gno.land/r/demo/wugnot" took=12.916¬µs
Proxy       ‚îÉ D unable to resolve path error="package not found" path="gno.land/r/volos.GetPositionSupplyShares(\"gno.land/r/demo/wugnot"
Proxy       ‚îÉ D connection closed in=127.0.0.1:51863 out=127.0.0.1:51737
Proxy       ‚îÉ D new connection remote=127.0.0.1:51865
Proxy       ‚îÉ D parsed request paths paths="[gno.land/r/volos.GetPositionBorrowShares(\"gno.land/r/demo/wugnot]"
```

The errors don't affect functionality, all queries are properly executed.

### 4. Auth warning

I am not sure what this warning is about, but I get it for every transaction (given address is the one signing the transactions):

```
Proxy       ‚îÉ D request handler warning error="unable to parse RPC request: unhandled: \"auth/accounts/g1tzl3sgre0c2zgxfpws9xhq0c069wf7zqh6aqqy\""
```

This also doesn't affect execution.

### 5. Incorrect Gnoweb URL

When using `-paths "gno.land/**"`, the Gnoweb port at `http://localhost:8888` incorrectly points to `http://gno.land/**` instead of `http://gno.land`.

### 6. Suggestion: Wildcard support for preloading single packages

Currently, using /* or /** doesn't work for single packages, you have to omit them entirely. It would be much more convenient if /* or /** also worked for single-package folders, so you don't have to think about whether a folder is a package itself or just a parent folder for multiple packages.

cc @gfanton

body: ‚ö†Ô∏è WIP: Transform gnoweb's source page to match pkg.go.dev's navigation experience, replacing direct code source display with a structured overview page. Fixes: #3665 ## Package Overview Page - **README at top**: Display README.md rendered in markdown if present - **Functions section**: List of exported functions with their signature and documentation - **Files section**: List of source files with links to individual code view - **Sidebar**: - ToC for the above - Metadata and stats info ## Metadata - **Package Info**: Module path, Gno version, Creator, Block Height - **Smart Badges**: Draft/Published, Private/Public, License/No License - **Statistics**: Files, functions, types, imports count - **Quality Indicators**: Tests (‚úì/‚úó), Documentation (‚úì/‚úó) ## Enhanced Navigation - **Package URL** (/r/package) ‚Üí Overview view (README + functions + files) - **Source URL without file** (/r/package$source) ‚Üí Overview view - **Source URL with file** (/r/package$source&file=main.gno) ‚Üí File source code (as before) - **Licence Auto-detection**: MIT, Apache-2.0, GNO-GPL, GPL, AGPL, BSD, ISC... - **Package Types**: realm, pure... ## Current Status (WIP) - [X] Overview view functional - [X] Navigation between overview and source code - [X] README, functions, files display - [x] Metadata - [ ] UI adjustments to better match pkg.go.dev and gno.land design - [ ] Tests and adjustments in progress ## UI/UX improvements planned - [ ] Reshape UX list of files design and packages (cf https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4441 to be improved) - [ ] Error handling and edge cases ## Screenshots

body:
### Description

Error when using gnokey to register a new user on Staging r/gnoland/users/v1 . It says "invalid package path".

### Your environment

* Go version go1.23.6
* OS and CPU architecture: macOS 15.5/M1
* Latest commit 5ad225f51aad97bbfda7a3307611fe3721ea41bc

### Steps to reproduce

Install the latest gnokey and generate a key:
```
git clone https://github.com/gnolang/gno
cd gno
make install
gnokey add testreg222
```
Copy the address. Go to https://faucet.gno.land . Click Staging. Add 20 GNOT (by adding 10 GNOT two times). Try to register the user:
```
gnokey maketx call -pkgpath "gno.land/r/gnoland/users/v1" -func "Register" -args "testreg222" -gas-fee 1000000ugnot -gas-wanted 50000000 -send "1000000ugnot" -broadcast -chainid "staging" -remote "https://rpc.gno.land:443" testreg222
```

### Expected behaviour

Should register the user on Staging.

### Actual behaviour

gnokey prints:
```
--= Error =--
Data: invalid package path
Msg Traces:
    0  /Users/jefft0/temp/invalidpath/gno/tm2/pkg/errors/errors.go:28 - deliver transaction failed: log:
--= /Error =--
```

### Proposed solution

title: feat(gnolang): consume gas when we allocate

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

labels.name: :package: :mountain:  gno.land
labels.description: Issues or PRs gno.land package related

body:
### Summary
This PR implements gas charging for memory allocations in the Gno virtual machine, providing better resource management

‚ö†Ô∏è High Impact Note: This change will significantly affect how we render and execute Gno programs, as memory allocations now consume gas. Operations that previously had predictable gas costs may now require substantially higher gas limits, especially for memory-intensive rendering operations.

### Changes Made

#### Core Implementation
- **Enhanced Allocator Structure**: Added `maxBytesUsed` tracking and `gasMeter` integration to the allocator
- **Gas Charging Logic**: Memory allocations now consume gas at a rate of 1 gas unit per byte allocated
- **Peak Memory Tracking**: Only charge gas when memory usage reaches a new peak, avoiding double-charging for temporary allocations

#### Key Features
- **Economic Memory Management**: Memory usage is now economically constrained through gas fees
- **GC Integration**: Works seamlessly with existing garbage collection mechanisms

#### Technical Details
```go
// New fields added to Allocator
maxBytesUsed int64        // Track peak memory usage
gasMeter     store.GasMeter // Integration with gas system

// Gas charging logic - only charge for new peaks
if alloc.bytes > alloc.maxBytesUsed {
    change := alloc.bytes - alloc.maxBytesUsed
    alloc.gasMeter.ConsumeGas(overflow.Mulp(change, GasCostPerByte), "memory allocation")
    alloc.maxBytesUsed = alloc.bytes
}
```

### Test Updates
Updated integration tests to reflect new gas consumption patterns:
- Basic operations: ~1-2K additional gas
- Package deployment: ~500 additional gas  
- Memory-intensive operations: Significant increases (GC test: 512K ‚Üí 262M gas)


### Breaking Changes
‚ö†Ô∏è **Gas Requirements**: Existing transactions may require higher gas limits due to memory allocation costs.

# Description

When set to `OriginCaller`, a situation occurs where NFT ownership cannot be transferred to other contracts, preventing `Mint` or `Approve` operations (we can think of a flow like user -> position -> staker). Therefore, we changed the caller to PrevRealm to handle this appropriately.

title: feat(gnovm, cli): Add profiling support

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

body:
# Description

This PR introduces comprehensive profiling capabilities to the Gno VM, enabling developers to analyze performance characteristics of their Gno programs. The implementation provides both standard profiling output formats and an interactive CLI similar to go tool pprof.

## Overview

The profiling system captures CPU cycles, memory allocations, and function call patterns during Gno program execution. It supports multiple output formats and includes an interactive analysis tool for exploring profile data.

## Key Features

### 1. Multiple Profile Types

- **CPU Profiling**: Tracks CPU cycles consumed by functions
- **Memory Profiling**: Records memory allocations and their locations
- **Line-level Profiling**: Provides granular performance data at the source line level

### 2. Flexible Output Formats

- **Text**: Human-readable summary of top functions
- **JSON**: Machine-readable format for integration with other tools
- **TopList**: Sorted list of functions by resource consumption
- **CallTree**: Hierarchical view of function calls and their costs

### 3. Interactive pprof-like CLI

A new `gno pprof` command provides an interactive interface similar to `go tool pprof`:

- Browse and filter profile data
- Focus on specific functions or packages
- Generate call trees and flame graphs
- Export filtered results

### 4. Integration with gno test

Profiling is seamlessly integrated into the testing workflow with new flags:

- `-profile`: Enable profiling
- `-profile-type`: Choose between cpu/memory profiling
- `-profile-output`: Specify output file location
- `-profile-format`: Select output format
- `-profile-list`: Generate line-by-line profile for specific functions

## Architecture

The implementation follows a modular design:

```
gnovm/pkg/profiler/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ profiler.go         # Core profiling engine
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ interfaces.go       # Abstract interfaces for VM integration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ linelevel.go       # Line-level profiling support
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ list.go            # Function listing and source annotation
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ visualization.go   # Output formatting and visualization
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ cli.go            # Interactive CLI implementation
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ cli_commands.go   # CLI command handlers
```

## Usage Examples

### Basic CPU Profiling

```bash
# Run tests with CPU profiling
gno test -profile -profile-output=cpu.prof ./examples/gno.land/p/demo/avl

# Analyze with interactive CLI
gno pprof cpu.prof
```

### Memory Profiling

```bash
# Profile memory allocations
gno test -profile -profile-type=memory -profile-output=mem.prof ./path/to/package

# View top memory consumers
gno pprof mem.prof
(pprof) top
```

### Line-by-line Analysis

```bash
# Profile specific function
gno test -profile -profile-list="gno.land/p/demo/avl.Set" ./examples/gno.land/p/demo/avl

# View annotated source
gno pprof cpu.prof
(pprof) list gno.land/p/demo/avl.Set
```

### Export Formats

```bash
# JSON output for external tools
gno test -profile -profile-format=json -profile-output=profile.json ./package

# Human-readable text format
gno test -profile -profile-format=text -profile-stdout ./package

# Call tree visualization
gno test -profile -profile-format=calltree -profile-stdout ./package
```

## Interactive CLI Commands

The `gno pprof` tool supports the following commands:

- `top [n]` - Show top N functions by flat time
- `list <function>` - Show annotated source for function
- `tree [function]` - Display call tree
- `focus <function>` - Focus on paths through a function
- `ignore <function>` - Ignore paths through a function
- `hide <function>` - Hide function from output
- `show` - Show current focus/ignore/hide settings
- `reset` - Clear all filters
- `save <file>` - Save filtered profile
- `help` - Show available commands
- `quit` - Exit profiler

## Implementation Details

### Machine Integration

The profiler integrates with the Gno VM through adapter interfaces, allowing clean separation between the VM internals and profiling logic:

```go
// MachineInfo provides VM state information
type MachineInfo interface {
    GetFrames() []FrameInfo
    GetCycles() int64
}

// FrameInfo provides call frame details
type FrameInfo interface {
    IsCall() bool
    GetFuncName() string
    GetFileName() string
    GetPkgPath() string
    GetSource() SourceInfo
}
```

title: ci: gnokms test failing randomly

labels.name: üêû bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

body:
## Description

Example of a run that failed: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/actions/runs/16519712019/job/46718566745#step:4:103

This panic occurs [here](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/2971303b6c8afe1af586586945c3cad4dd3a764c/contribs/gnokms/internal/common/flags.go#L19-L25) if both `os.UserConfigDir()` and `os.Getwd()` functions return an error. It seems related to a misconfigured environment on some GitHub Actions runners. 

## Hypothesis

I strongly suspect that some misconfigured self-hosted runners are responsible for the issue. 

To be sure, I think we should:
- Create a GitHub Actions workflow of type ‚Å†[workflow_dispatch](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/events-that-trigger-workflows#workflow_dispatch)‚Ä©	- Create a job with two steps:
1. The first step logs the content of the [runner context](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/reference/contexts-reference#runner-context) to check whether the current run is executed by a `self-hosted` runner or a `github-hosted` runner.

```yaml
      - name: Dump Runner context
        env:
          RUNNER_CONTEXT: ${{ toJson(runner) }}
        run: echo "$RUNNER_CONTEXT"
```

2. The second step creates a simple `main.go` file and then ‚Å†`go run` it.‚Ä©	

```go
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
)

func main() {
	if _, err := os.UserConfigDir(); err != nil {
		fmt.Println("Cannot get user config directory:", err)
		os.Exit(1)
	}

	if _, err := os.Getwd(); err != nil {
		fmt.Println("Cannot get current working directory:", err)
		os.Exit(1)
	}

	fmt.Println("Environment is set up correctly.")
}
```

- Then, we should repeatedly execute the ‚Å†`workflow_dispatch` until it fails and check if the run was executed on a self-hosted runner.

title: feat(gnovm): consume gas when we preprocess

labels.name: :package: :robot: gnovm
labels.description: Issues or PRs gnovm related

labels.name: review/triage-pending
labels.description: PRs opened by external contributors that are waiting for the 1st review

body:
## PR Description

**Summary:**  
This PR introduces gas metering to the preprocessing phase of the Gno VM. It adds a `gasMeter` parameter to key preprocessing and AST traversal functions, ensuring that gas is consumed during static analysis and preprocessing, not just during execution.

**Key Changes:**
- Added `gasMeter` parameter to functions like `Preprocess`, `PredefineFileSet`, `initStaticBlocks`, and `Transcribe`.
- Updated all relevant call sites to pass the machine‚Äôs gas meter where available.
- Gas is now consumed for each node processed during AST traversal.
- All gas metering is null-safe for backward compatibility.

---

## Possible Improvements

- **Granularity:** The current implementation charges a flat gas cost per node. We could refine this by charging based on node type or estimated complexity.
